game-hours: 366.5
review: There's not much to say about Team Fortress 2, considering the fact that it is free to play and is availilbe instantly to anyone who joins Steam. TF2 has become THE quintisential Vavle gam, the best representative of that company and to an extent of Steam. Nevertheless, in the event that there are people out there who have not yet tried this game, this review is for you. Team Fortress 2 is the result of almost 9 years of work by the Vavle comanpy, the same company that brought you the Left 4 Dead, Half-Life, and Portal series. The basic idea of TF2, a basic team-based shooter with 9 classes of soldiers to choose from, was founded back in the days of Quake, which quickly gave rise to Team Fortress Classic. Once Valve had the model they were after for Team Fortress, they spent years refining and programming it into the monsterous, magnificent behemoth that is TF2. When it was originally released, it was regarded as the pinnacle of shooters. You also had to buy it to play it. I was among those who bought TF2 in the short time after it was released. At first I wasn't particularly enthused by the game. I was more used to the Call of Duty format of shooters, with rapid action, lone-wolf tactics, instant kills, instant deaths, and a basic but highly customizable point-and-shoot mechanic to the game. TF2 has highly specialized classes, team strategy, and weapons that aren't exactly point-and-shoot-for-instant-kill. I was upset at the general lack of customization availible, although what kept me occasionally coming back for more was the fact that TF2 ha a wide variety of game modes, all of which require very different strategies on the part of players. You can't simply treat every class the same way in every game mode. So I wasn't a regular at TF2. Didn't play enough to get any good at it. But then things began to change, and they changed for the better. First, the game aquired more items and weapons for each of the different classes, allowing for a greater level of customization than what previously existed. Then, the game became free to play; which brought along with it scores of other benifits. A)- Free to play means more players, which means a better variety of skills and skill-sets, and more games availible at any given time. B)- A new set of training missions, meant to help noobs find their way a little bit. So sweet. C)- Constant updates with new weapons, items, maps, and game modes. In effect, Team Fortress 2 has become that dream game: a shooter that requires teamwork and strategy, that is constantly updated and is always having things added to it, and is played by virtually all computer-gamers in one form or another. I won't talk much about the game itself, because again, most of you have already played it, or can fidn stuff out for yourself since you all have it automatically, but here we go: The nine classes, each with distinct abilities and weapons, both of the greatest variety that there has ever been in a video game, are... -SOLDIER- Shoots rockets, moves sorta slow, but has good health. Usually carries a shotgun and melee as well. -SCOUT- Runs fast, shoots shotguns and pistols, carries a baseballbat. -HEAVY- Big guy, big health, big gun (a minigun!), moves slow. -SNIPER- A one-hit-kill wonder, with a sniper rifle and assorted secondaries. -MEDIC- He heals, runs fast, and in MvM he can bring you back from the dead! -PYRO- Fire. -DEMOMAN- Runs medium speed with a grenade launcher, a sticky bomb launcher, and a variety of Scottish-themed melee weapons. -ENGINEER- Builds sentry guns, health and ammo dispensers, and teleporters. -SPY- Diguises as enemies and then backstabs them at high speeds. There are a variety of game modes. -PAYLOAD- Push a cart with a bomb through a series of maps. -PAYLOAD RACE- Two carts, one map. -CAPTURE THE FLAG- Steal a shinny briefcase from the enemy. -ARENA- Basic team deathmatch, but you only have one life. -CONTROL POINT- Battle it out for control of...well, points! Comes in symetrical mode (both teams have even numbers of points) and attack/defend mode (one team starts with all the points). -KING OF THE HILL- Requires no explaining. -MANN VS MACHINE- The only co-op mode, in which you fight waves of enemy robots. Think Nazi-Zombies, but the game has an end. -SPECIAL DELIVERY- There is one suitcase, and one rocket. First team to get said suitcase to said rocket wins. ...AND probably a few that I have forgotten. The maps are of a great variety and all are filled with multiple ways of getting from one place to another. There is something for everyone: secret passages, sniper perches, saferooms, and other elements that allow each class to preform at it's best, so long as you know how to exploit each map to your advantage. Team Fortress 2 is immensley fun, easy enough to get good at, and is absolutely massive in terms of items, game modes, maps, and community. There is not any real reason not to play this game, unless of course you just don't want to. I'd give TF2 a 9 out of 10.

game-hours: 0.8
review: Team Fortress 2... one of the best multiplayer games i've ever played and that's impressive considering it's a shooter. The 9 different classes and an entire armory of weapons keeps the gameplay and variety flowing. This game was released in 2007 and it's still relevant today which is impressive for today's standards. Not to mention the chat which is always a good thing. Each class is unique with their own playstyles and abilities with weapons that cater to one playstyle or another. There is an assortment of different maps and gamemodes, all of them unique and fun to play. There's also hats which you can collect and wear for no purpose other then looking good. These hats are all different and you will always find a hat that you like. The graphics are wonderfully cartoony, being based off of early 21st century artists like Norman Rockwell. Each character has their own unique charming personalities, suiting them well and making them more funny with their quotes. Overall, i think Team Fortress 2 is a great multiplayer game having both excellent gameplay and funny charm. I give this game 10/10

review: How to Properly Play the Game Step 1: Do nothing Step 2: Once you did nothing for about 50 hours, you will earn a hat Step 3: Jump onto a trade server Step 4: As you connect yourself to the server, brace yourself for sprays that are not suitable for minors Step 5: Ignore the Rainbow Dash booty call spray and type in chat "Selling hat" Step 6: Once you accepted his/her trade, crush their soul and steal their hats Step 7: Once you have crushed enough souls, you will become rich Step 8: Amass your wealth to get an Unusual, which is an amalgamation of pixels floating around the hat Step 9: Play the shooting mini-game that comes along with Hat Simulator 2, and get beaten in a gunfight against a free to play person wearing an achievement hat Step 10: Punch a hole through your computer and hang yourself

game-hours: 334.1
review: Team Fortress 2 is a free to play class-based game with 9 classes. These classes include Scout, Soldier, Pyro, Demoman, Heavy, Engineer, Medic, Sniper and spy. Each class has its won unique play style and weaponry. All the classes loadout consist of a primary weapon, secondary weapon and melee weapon. There is also weapons you can find by playing the game. There is also hats you can find,make or buy. If you are planning on buying a hat i recommend buying them on the community market which may be for a cheaper price. You can also buy weapons on the community market that arent normal weapons instead they are strange, killstreaking, botkillers and festive even though they are different than the normal weapons they sell for less than the store on tf2 (note this dosent apply for all weapons). I recommend not to buy anything untill you are sure you like tf2 and you will be playing for a while. This is a great game to play with friends to be competitive or goof around . This happens to be the game me and my friends play together the most we really like to join games with no one in them and play eacother. It is also a advantage to have a friend who plays tf2 cause you can trade wit hthen and you can give them a weapon you dont want but they do and they can give you one they dont want. You could also count on a good deal with trades from a friend. There is many game modes in tf2. These game modes are Control points, King of the Hill, Special delivery, Payload, Payload race, Capture the flag and Attack/Defence. Each game mode has a different objective than the others. Attack/denfence is my favorite. Each game mode takes skill to master. Im not even that good at all the game modes or the game in general yet. Thats all i have to say about this great game for now but i may edit it and add more so keep your eyes open. ~nobel~

review: An absolutely wonderful game for those who want a LEVEL playing field. Sure there will be bugs from time to time when they add new items and/or facets to the game but, unlike most others, they meticulously work to make sure that the playing field is FAIR. This isn't Call of Duty where you can earn "CheaterPro" from 17th prestige and stomp all over the new kid simply because he's new...it's all based on skill. Sure a lot of people disliked the addition of the store, the ability to buy new weapons before others have them...but they're all side-grades with very little advantage in terms of power. Strategy and skill are key and, if all else fails, there's plenty of maps to troll about on! Don't take yourself so srsly all the time :>, have fun, laugh.

game-hours: 940.8
review: I have owned Team Fortress 2 for quite a while now, but only until it was made Free to Play. But I couldn't figure out how to explain it for a while now... Let's try this: Team Fortress 2 is very different. Although some First Person Shooters are very serious, dark, etc., TF2 takes a light-hearted approach to the genre, with cartoony graphics (but bloody), many jokes and dialouge, and the "Darn-this-let's-attack-the-enemy-head-on" feel of the game. Besides the reasons I just stated above, TF2 is very, very different from other FPS games. There's no leveling, EXP, upgrades of any kind. Instead, you do achievements to get milestones and get guns, however those guns have advantages and setbacks compared to the original gun, to be evened out. And besides, you can either pay with real money to buy the gun, or be lucky and "find" it while playing (you'll know what I'm talking about when it comes around.) There are other differences, but I'm running out of space. D: Try it yourself!

review: This game is by far one of the best games on Steam other than GMod(which i will review in later times). Valve always makes good games and this one is proof of that theory. While it is frustrating that other people have better stuff than you most likely because they paid for that cool taunt, hat, costume, or weapon, and you can't download DLC for free but instead have to wait for Valve or Steam to add new stuff because of the number of stars it gets in the workshop, the classes do balance each other out. The game is always getting good stuff, and the community is great. It's the best multiplayer game because it forces you to work with others to achieve the goal. Mann vs. Machine is very fun too, because you're working with a small group to kill and survive waves of robots that impose as different classes. The classes are great because there is a class for every type of player. I prefer Heavy, Soldier, Pyro, and Spy while my friend prefers Sniper and Medic. This game is not very serious and the players should not take themselves or anybody else in the game seriously. My friend and I were doing the Conga taunt and we were kicked off the server because we weren't shooting at the enemies. I also like that when you explode you most of the time blow up into bloody bits and if a sniper gets a headshot it blows your head of it's shoulders! All that should be added is when you get shot enough in one body part it flies off and a gametype that most everyone loves, TEAM DEATHMATCH! This would heighten my interest along with many others. I can't commentate on the economy in the game because I just started the game and have not seen what it was like before. The only bad thing about this game really is that some weapons don't do crap and you should smelt them for better things or trade them as soon as you get them, like the Black Box! It's really a downgrade from the level 1 Rocket Launcher. That's all for my review of TEAM FORTRESS 2 and i give it a 9.9/10.

game-hours: 811.2
review: A beautiful game with sufficient graphics, amazingly balanced gameplay and well-defined characters. Each class has its own strengths and weaknesses- but these go far and away beyond the generic 'water-beats-fire-beats-grass-beats-water' system. The gameplay is much more intricate than that. For example, let us look at the Pyro. The Pyro, being a relatively short-range class, must almost always ambush the Heavy instead of face him in direct combat to have a decent chance of dispatching the large Russian beast. Even so, the Pyro's skills must be of a certain standard to kill the aforementioned Heavy. This Heavy, however, is slow and known to be fodder for Spies, especially when preoccupied with firing at other foes. A swift backstab severs the mortal thread of Heavy. The Spy, though, relies on deceit and opportunism to kill, and is all but dead when faced with a Pyro, due to his fragile health and the Pyro's high movement speed and ability to deal a painful stream of fire. Thus, the cycle is brought full-circle. Furthermore, a Spy's sapper causes headaches for Engineers, whose Sentry Guns are a considerable obstacle to Pyros, whose airblast ability provides a beautiful (often touted as overpowered) counter to Demomen and Soldiers, whose projectiles are arguably the most threatening to a Sentry if no Spy is present... Team Fortress 2 boasts complex, intricate gameplay that is an absolute pleasure to experience once one picks it up.

game-hours: 658.9
review: Why aren't you playing this game already? It is never too late to start, and it will never be pay2win. The best players at the professional level use weapons with the same stats as what you are given upon booting it up, so don't worry about that. All the weapons with different stats are sidegrades, not upgrades, and the stock weapons are the most useful most of the time. There's a diverse, completely optional economy around cosmetics, which can be ignored if you just want to shoot people. While there isn't a single player, there is co-op that is quite entertaining. The community is very friendly. Play this now, put on a hat, and don't play pyro or spy as your first class. Instead, how about medic?

review: This game is so awesome, especially because it is free to play! Join in with your friends on the action paced game, including 9 different classes! Scout - Capture enemy objectives to help out your team! Soldier - Blow your enemies to pieces and rocket jump to get around the map faster! Pyro - Burn your enemies to the ground and spycheck for enemy spies! Demoman - Place stickies on your objectives to blow enemies to pieces when they try to capture it! Heavy - Defend points with much toughness and a high rate of fire with your Minigun! Enginer - Build your own base including a sentry gun, dispenser and teleporters to help out your team! Medic - Heal your allies, use bercharge to give a teammate and yourself invulnerability! Sniper - Pick of easy targets from a distance with 1 shot to the head! Spy - Disguise and lure the enemy team you are one of them, get behind them and backstab them with your knife! A highly recommended game!

game-hours: 17.9
review: I now have over 10 hours on this game (10.4 to be exact), so I believe I deserve an opinion. Also, I plan to update this review after I have played it for 100, 1000 and 10,000 (if i survive this long) hours to see how my opinion changes and how much value this game saves over time. I am not a fan of FPS games, and the only reason I downloaded this game was "why the hell not, it's free and looks alright". I am very happy I made this decision, since this is one of the best games I have ever played. It is full of action, variety, and, most importantly, explosions! Also, hats. Even though there are items you can purchase for real money in game, they are not necessary. I have enjoyed the game for 8.5 hours before deciding to purchase a sniper rifle, and there is not much difference before and after the upgrade. The game is also a very polished product, no annoyances, only enjoyances. Very good cartoony graphics, subtle humor rarely found in FPS games, and many gameplay options to choose from. Can't recommend this enough, so all kinds of gamers. Whether or not you are a FPS fan, give this game a try, you will be pleasantly surprised.

game-hours: 164.1
review: Team Fortress 2 has the most balanced classes around with some being more for new players and others being for the more experienced. Take the sniper. The sniper is the easiest class in the game and it is extremely easy to use. It is recommended to try and shoot the body and not the head, as it does almost the same amount of damage. The pyro however, is almost impossible to master and the people who are able to use it well have been called w+m1-ers. This stands for win+medic1, because a pyro and a medic are almost unstoppable and can win the game if the pyro has any decent amount of skill. The heavy is also one of the harder class, and the win+medic1 also applies to it. There are many great game modes and maps, but I love deathmatch on 2fort myself.

game-hours: 50.6
review: its fun and cool
game-hours: 2125.5
review: You know, After playing this game since 2008. I've never actually given this game a fair review, but I suppose it's about time I gave this game a decent and fair analysis. To put it simply, Team Fortress 2 is the ultimate multiplayer game. Since it's release in 2007, multiple updates by the creator, Valve and it's dedicated community have extended the lifespan of the game almost indefinitely. Players who tried the beta of the game prior to the release, could never of imagined the direction the game would take to the time of this review in 2014. First of all, the game is Free to Play, so if you haven't tried this game, there is absolutely no reason as to why you shouldnt try it. Secondly, since the game is technically 7 years old, the actual spec that your PC needs to the run the game is actually incredibly low, so even if you have an old rig, you should be able to run the game in a lower quality setting. Handy, right? The amount of game types the player is given to play is staggering, from offical game types such as the popular Payload, Attack and Defence, and even lesser known game types such as Territorial Control will all be able to entertain you for hours upon end. However, as mentioned before, the community have offered their hand in providing additonal game types, such as Deathrun and 'Saxton Hale' mode. Not a fan of Multiplayer? Fine, try out Mann Vs Machine mode. It works as a Co-Op mode that can be played between 6 players. Despite being known commonly nowadays as a 'Hat Simulator' the game actually has it's own in depth economy in selling hats and virtual equipment. Just be careful of scammers! Wrapping this review up, the game is quite simply, amazing. The fact that is still lives and breathes even stronger than what it did 6 years ago is outstanding. But why are you still reading this review? Go play TF2!

review: After playing more than 100 hours,TF2 proves to be a very excellent game.whether you are mastering stock weapons as a free to play,or filling your backpack to the max with rare items,tf2 will last you at least 2 years.every class has a unique way to play with certin abilities that are sometimes the only way to dominate.the game has so many maps that you cant even play them all until a new one comes out from either valve themselves or by a steam user who has a custom one.there is almost no way to 100% this game until you find hundreds of items and earn every achievment possible.there are new players each day so you can never meet them all.Not only does it have lots of maps,but also many gametypes including a co-op mode thats something more original enemy than zombies.gametypes include capture the flag,control points,and many more.With its 100% free status its a must have game for any account.

game-hours: 399.5
review: TF2 ruined my relationship.
game-hours: 935.9
review: I had started playing TF2 when it came out in 2007. Me and my cousin would enjoy it for hours on end, and the community was just starting. I was addicted to this shooter, with its' cartoon-like graphics and simple objectives. Then all sorts of weapons and headgear/ misc items were released throughout the years, and the game turned into something different; an economy. It's hard to enjoy the game when it's filled with trade servers and all sorts of random junk, but it didn't stop me from finding some amazing communities. As time progressed, I started to get bored of the same old thing. Until I found new modded gamemodes like VS. Saxton Hale, Deathrun, TF2Ware, Slender Fortress 2, and more. My interest soared with playing these games, but eventually, I decided to quit. The community is heading downhill, and I chose to put my items in the market in hopes I can gain some money back. All-in-all, Team Fortress 2 is a great game, but is also a dying one. Hopefully something drastic will happen so I may come back to it.

review: ^ The hours that I have played. This is ridiculous. No game I have ever played had this many hours on it. EVER. This game has everything a FPS could ask for. Its got some humor in it with the funny descriptions and the wierd combinations you can get with cosmetics. It has a very strong economy from Backpack.tf (where people can vote on item prices) and from trading. This game is very heavily community based. The best part about that is the community is kind and lively. People are constantly submitting new items into the Steam Workshop in hoping that it may be put into the game. This game you can trade, suggest, have fun, and play. All of this, for free. Just consider this before you go to the store and decide to buy that $40 FPS. Can you trade? Can you take part in a large community? Can you have fun even if you are losing the match? Just think about what Team Fortress 2 has to offer. All of this. For free.

game-hours: 217.1
review: One of the first pictorial depictions of a hat appears in a Thebes tomb painting which shows a man wearing a conical straw hat. Other early hats were the Pileus, a simple skull cap; the Phrygian cap, worn by freed slaves in Greece and Rome; and the Greek petasos, the first known hat with a brim. Women wore veils, kerchiefs, hoods, caps and wimples. St. Clement, the patron saint of felt hatmakers, is said to have discovered wool felt when he filled his sandals with flax fibers to protect his feet.[4] In the Middle Ages, hats were a marker of social status and used to single out certain groups. The 1215 Fourth Council of the Lateran required that all Jews identify themselves by wearing the Judenhat (Jewish hat), marking them as targets for anti-Semitism.[5]The hats were usually yellow, and were either pointed or square. [6] In the Middle Ages, hats for women ranged from simple scarves to elaborate hennin,[7] and denoted social status. Structured hats for women similar to those of male courtiers began to be worn in the late 16th century.[8] The term milliner comes from the Italian city of Milan, where the best quality hats were made in the 18th century. Millinery was traditionally a womans occupation, with the milliner not only creating hats and bonnets but also choosing lace, trimmings and accessories to complete an outfit.[9] Men's hat, 1600-1625 In the first half of the 19th century, women wore bonnets that gradually became larger, decorated with ribbons, flowers, feathers, and gauze trims. By the end of the century, many other styles were introduced, among them hats with wide brims and flat crowns, the flower pot and the toque. By the middle of the 1920s, when women began to cut their hair short, they chose hats that hugged the head like a helmet.[8] The tradition of wearing hats to horse racing events began at the Royal Ascot in Britain, which maintains a strict dress code. All guests in the Royal Enclosure must wear hats.[10] This tradition was adopted at other horse racing events, such as the Kentucky Derby in the United States.[11] Extravagant hats were popular in the 1980s, and in the early 21st century, flamboyant hats made a comeback, with a new wave of competitive young milliners designing creations that include turban caps, trompe-l'oeil-effect felt hats and tall headpieces made of human hair. Some new hat collections have been described as "wearable sculpture." Many pop stars, among them Lady Gaga, have commissioned hats as publicity stunts.[12]

review: This game has been around for almost 7 years might go for it's tenth year and I could see why. You can customize your charactor with whatever apperal or hats. Whether you wanna make look badass or just flat out stupid the choices are yours. game-hours: 1657.2
review: The best multiplayer experience you can get!
game-hours: 1450.2
review: Team Fortress 2 is, dare I say, one of the most innovative FPS games of all time. With nine different classes to choose from and battle with other online users head on in different game modes, the combinations are endless. The graphics of this game are somewhat simple, but stylized in such a way that reminds me of a comic book, which is very appealing. Being able to customize your loadout and collect hats, miscs, taunts, etc. the possibilities are endless. The community is also a competitive group of people, all around the world going for the top of the scoreboard, or the community that strives to get that one certain hat, and have the richest backpack. Now, a few downsides would be some of the exploitable bugs, but that's not too big of a deal. Valve is very good with fixing the bugs found nowadays. The annoying downtimes from item servers can be an annoyance as well, but aside from those few things it is overshadowed by Team Fortress 2's greatness. With more being added frequently, the involvement with the community, and addicting gameplay, TF2 is given a solid 9.5/10

review: 9.5/10 If you've been in a cave for the last 7 years, then you may have not heard of a "Little" game called TF2. TF2 is a class-based FPS, i. e. different characters and loadouts. TF2 strays away from the militaristic style of TF1, and adds a breath of fresh air to the FPS industry, unlike the MONOTONOUS BLACK OPS S- Oops, did I get ahead of myself. The gameplay is so unique, you'll be hooked for life. Every single weapon is different. From rocket launchers to shotguns to pistols to soda to conch shells to lasers to exploding cannon balls - whew. The beauty of this game lies in its totally unique item system. You can acquire items by playing the game, buying them (Hey, they gotta make a profit), or by crafting them. Weapons are used to put up a fight, hats are hard to acquire, but are worth a lot and can make you look like a boss, and tools can be used for various purposes, like opening crates or spreading keys. However, it is F2P, but in a good way. The people who buy the stuff have no clear advantage over the F2Pers. The best part of the game is the classes. They all are different and unique. Take the Soldier. Soldier is your one man army, armed with a RPG, a shotgun, and a shovel, although like all classes, this can be changed. He is a steryotypical crazed patriot from the midwest, and is smart as a pecan. (Not smart). There's also a co-op mode against robots, literal robots who run on piles of money, and the game's fan base can create content on GMOD, increasing the media for this game. One major thing that iffs me is that some things you can unbox from Mann Co Supply Crates (A gimmick for you to buy keys to get a mystery prize) are not even worth how much the key was worth. Stranges and strange parts are sometimes looked down on in the community. Other then that, it's great.

review: One day, I noticed a game I had heard about went free. This day was all the way back in June 2011. The game was Team Fortress 2. Now, TF2 is one of my favorite games--perhaps even my #1. Why? There's a multitude of reasons, but the combination of skill-based shooting, fast gameplay, and completely absurd customization made this game absolutely amazing. I'd definitely recommend Team Fortress 2 to anyone--except Rohan. I tried. He hated it. Apparently the "bad graphics" and "unrealistic look" made him not like the game, as well as the fact that it "wasn't realistic enough because rockets don't kill in one hit". Rohan's an idiot. If Rohan ever recommends a game, don't listen to him. He's an idiot. Don't be an idiot. Don't be Rohan. Play Team Fortress 2. Piss off Rohan and anybody like him with your fancy $5000 spooky glowing golden frying pan . 10/10 would hat simulate again.

game-hours: 17.9
review: I now have over 10 hours on this game (10.4 to be exact), so I believe I deserve an opinion. Also, I plan to update this review after I have played it for 100, 1000 and 10,000 (if i survive this long) hours to see how my opinion changes and how much value this game saves over time. I am not a fan of FPS games, and the only reason I downloaded this game was "why the hell not, it's free and looks alright". I am very happy I made this decision, since this is one of the best games I have ever played. It is full of action, variety, and, most importantly, explosions! Also, hats. Even though there are items you can purchase for real money in game, they are not necessary. I have enjoyed the game for 8.5 hours before deciding to purchase a sniper rifle, and there is not much difference before and after the upgrade. The game is also a very polished product, no annoyances, only enjoyances. Very good cartoony graphics, subtle humor rarely found in FPS games, and many gameplay options to choose from. Can't recommend this enough, so all kinds of gamers. Whether or not you are a FPS fan, give this game a try, you will be pleasantly surprised.

review: The game is nothing like CoD or Battlefield, and its graphics, as some people say it is terrible, is kind of good for a 'cartoon' styled world, rather than a more realistic theme, but this does make it easier to tell the classes of the other players you are playing with. The game is NOT pay-to-win as some people will say, the standard weapons are good, and can kill people who are using unique guns, as the other guns have drawbacks which make it more fair and not overpowered, such as one of the scouts bats dealing damage to yourself if you miss the enemy, causing you to bleed too. BUT, be warned that, due to it being 'cartoon' styled, be sure you are capable of putting up with kids spamming or using the ingame voicechat, or just quickly mute them from the game menu.

review: This Game made me great in FPS games, It my skills in FPS sharper and look at me now ALMOST NO ONE CAN STOP ME! But Beware you Might end up unlucky. Well to me i dont care if its gonna be lucky or not when im in a serious battle LOL i don't depend on Rare ITEMS or guns,accessories or etc,INSTEAD I USE DEFAULT WEAPONS RATHER THAN USING MY OTHER STRONG GUNS.. STILL THIS is my review!Team Fortress 2 is the most realistic hat simulator created to date. There is absolutely no other simulator quite like this one. The first time you start the simulator, you join a server where you can play a minigame where you show off your hats and items. If you kill a person three times in a row in the minigame, you get your very first hat: the Gibus. This is where it really starts; To play the simulator correctly, you have to spend money in the market place, made by Valve. After that, while you play the minigame, you can find hats which you can trade for, or collect! There is many other people who wants to collect and trade hats, just like you! After you collect enough items and/or hats, try joining a trade server! There, the REAL fun begins! Good luck!

game-hours: 1299.5
review: Had it for 5 years and only decided to start playing it at the start of 2014 and haven't stopped since! The reason? Well this action packed, round based, comedy driven and absolute ball of fun FPS Multiplayer, is everything you need to have the most fun you could ever get out of gaming and I don't say that lightly! It has 9 very diverse classes you can choose from, all with their own rediculous back story and style of gameplay. Each class is given stock weapons, but can get unique weapons from: *Random drops. *Trading (if you're premium). *Buying from the store. *Gifts. Every weapon can have added cosmetic effects, like killstreaks (every kill done in that specific life, is reset when you're killed) or strange (the amount of kills comitted by the weapon with the specific weapon the strange is added onto), which can have their own sheens on the weapon and more. There are 7 official gamemodes for standard multiplayer and 1 official gamemode for COOP multiplayer, each are quite diverse in gameplay and maps. There are also cosmetics that can be added to your character to make them look snazzy or silly, these are called hats, although there are clothes as well. All this and it's free! (If you don't want to buy anything from the store) I recommend atleast buying the $5 premium, so that you can trade and recieve random hat drops. This game offers so much for so little in return, you have to try it! Anyhow, I give this a 9.5/10, even though it's graphics are outdated, it doesn't matter, the graphics for this game suit it and it won't age at all!

review: Team Fortress 2. Ah, how amazing it is. This game is one of the best things to happen to me. Why? Because of the sheer awsomeness of it is hard to understand by using words, but i'll try. This game is a fast paced fps that puts you in a seemingly cartoony world where flying drunken sword swiping bomb chucking sticky trapping black scotish cyclopes exist, you already know this is one of the best f2p games you will pick up. This game is different from all the rest, not only because of how it looks, but of the gameplay and classes avalible. the story is told through comics, and thats fine with me.there are 9 classes, The Scout, a fast running loudmouth from Bosten, The Heavy, a Russin family man that will make you piss yourself everytime he opens his mouth, The Engineer, the gentile Texen that can build a sentry that will make your life living hell (if it wasent already), The Demoman, the scotish drunk that you heard about earlyer,The Spy, the french devilish snake that will sneak into the back lines, as well as your mothers bed, The Sniper, a assassin for hire from Austrailia that will take your head off in .5 seconds flat, The Medic, the sasistic healer from Germany that will heal your team as well as stick his medi-gun up the heavys (beeep), The Soldier, the crazy American nut that can blow you into a million giblits, as well as be a flying killing machine that will stick a shovel in the back of your head, and The Pyro, the Pyromaniac that gender is unknown (MatPat's theory has been disproved, sorry) that will w+mi as well as airblast his way through everyone. And that doesnt even cover the gameplay. if you think you should give this game a try, then you are very right. I hope this review helped you, goodbye and gooday, mate (headshots)

game-hours: 181.6
review: Team Fortress 2 (In case you didn't know) is a class-based first person shooter created by Valve (also owner of Steam). There and nine classes in Team Fortress 2 which are: Scout, Soldier, Pyro, Demoman, Heavy, Engineer, Medic, Sniper and Spy all of which have very humorous personalities, often times very stereotypical. Each class has it's own play-style and a variation of different weapons. It includes about seven different multiplayer modes and it's own game mode called Man vs Machine or MvM for short, in which you fight off against waves of robots trying to protect Mann Co. In a summary, this is a very addicting FPS that I would definitely recommend to anybody who has some spare time, and feels like shooting some dudes up!

review: This is a well made, stylized, team based first person shooter. Teamwork is needed to win at higher levels of play, though lone wolfing is fine on lower skill levels such as on most public servers. There are 9 classes to choose from. Each class has unique weapons and abilities that allow each to fill a unique roll as part of a larger team. This provides for a challenging and rewarding experience when faced against opponents of similar or better skill levels.

review: Great for casual gamers who like fps.
game-hours: 182.3
review: Anything above a 90 on the metascore is a title you should play. Team Fortress 2 was planned to be a FPS/RTS hybrid in it's early stages but turned out to be one of the most respected and solid FPS titles that doesn't want to be realistic or yet another military based game. The "non-photorealistic" rendering as per it's technical name, is system taxing. That machine on which Half Life 2 runs perfectly on, will see a dip in frame rates (and enjoyment) unless the system is able to handle the higher standards of graphics. The scandal of turning from a paid model into a Free 2 Play model, has people refusing to pick the game up again. The cost of the game was around $15-$20 way back when, and came in the ye' old Orange Box. Profits after doing so increased 2 fold, which is a little known fact. Don't be suprised if you see "Man Co. Store" a lot, which is the paid item store run by Valve. Enjoyment is sure to be found, as it's not really a FPS. The community still calls it a "hat simulator" to this day, thanks to the player class customization. Serious play isn't to be found here. Sit back and just play. Again this is another team based game with 9 classes to choose from. A multitude of weapons and other items for each class will allow you to stand out. 8/10
game-hours: 1993.2
review: Awesome first person! Sadly playing other games when missing the launch of this game! Mega sad face :( Awesome game 9/10.
game-hours: 358.3
review: Pros: 1. Game is free. 2. Runs on same engine as games such as Portal 2. 3. Microtransactions are available, but it is set up so that every weapon has its own pros and cons(just because you buy a weapon you won't be op), and you can find and craft them all just by playing the game fairly easy. Clothing and such is also available. You won't have second-class equipment if you don't buy anything. 4. Can waste your life on this game like I did and then sell the stuff you find and craft for cold hard steam store credit. 5. One of the most played games on Steam. Has players 24/7. 6. Game is fun. Cons: 1. You found free FPS perfection. You have nothing to look forward to in life.
game-hours: 1054.6
review: ITS FREAKKIN AWSOME
game-hours: 1114.7
review: TL:DR: at the end It was 2011, I had been wandering around best buy when i saw a box case for team fortress 2 for 10 dollars. I wondered why they would be selling the same minimalist game i played on the orange box on my xbox, so i wandered over to the computer section of the store and looked up why someone would buy it on PC. I found that the PC version had more than the 10 maps on the xbox version, it had differnt weapons to pick from and hats too, i thought oh what the hell, and got the game. I came home to set it up on my old cruddy toshiba laptop and as a result caused me to create a steam account, but it couldn't hande it, so i used my brother's laptop whenever he wasn't using it. I fell in love instantly. The multitudes of gamemodes, the custom maps and many achievements to get (and i was an achievement addict back then thanks to my xbox) kept me entertained. My brother got a virus on his computer and blames the custom maps i downloaded because of it (to this day, im not sure if it was the cause). So he didn't let me use it anymore almost a year later it was early 2012, somehow i convinced my brother to play on his computer again when i found out that a few months earlier the game became free to play. A ton of my friends began playing it which made it appealing again. When i came back though everything was about trading, not many went to achievement servers anymore, there were spreadsheets, and things that used to be worth very little (buds were 2 keys and bills were 1) were now jacked up in price. I got used to it though, and adapted to become a good trader, i even met a guy who i called my "partner" and we worked together to trade our way up, and it worked. We got a fireproof diary (which i still dont know what it does) out of pyromania. Despite me finding the deal, he wanted to hold on to it. And around that time i felt him becoming more hostile, I was kind of afraid to ask him to much out of fear that he would run off with the whole thing. And despite my pleads in saying that it would probably triple in value soon (it only doubled, but i was still kind of right) he decided to sell it anyway. And because of my conversations with him being too cautious, he only gave me 25% ( 5 keys out of 20) and i couldn't really do much about it. I was angry. So i created a scheme in which i created a fake account and pretended i had some crazy amount to offer him in a spycrab (look it up if you dont know what it is) and knowing him, he said he had an equal amount (which he didn't). I got lucky and i won it and just like i thought, he changed his name and did a bunch of other things to hide himself. I then used a new fake account (which i pretended was a steam admin of something like that) and told him when he was reported for the spycrab, i investigated and found that the bud he used to have was duped (look that up too). He practically bribed me to keep quiet and i got back a good share of what was mine. He still doesn't know i did this to this day. I lost my tf2 privalages again until late 2013, this year, when i got my own computer. And this was the best time of all for me. From all my previous trading i had a ton of items which raised in value while i was away, i decided (as i didn't need most of it) to do giveaways in different servers. One server in particular (sodahappy) i met a kind admin (still good friends with) who helped me do some giveaways using his admin powers, this influenced me to join the community and become a moderator (so i could do giveways). For a while it was fun. People didn't do the giveaways for only free stuff, but for the fun minigames it had. Such as one where everyone was locked in a small room and had to try and run away while i used a /zap function which killed them if i pressed a button while aiming at them. But then problems started to occur, my giveaways started to become out of hand as everyone was doing them. People no longer cared for the game than the prize. And i got in trouble with the higher up admins because of the amount of zaps ( i had 2800 zaps in the 4 months i was a mod, other mods had no more than 100 in their entire careers). After explaing that issue and a few others i was restricted in giveaways. And over time i got less enthusiastic with it. I left Sodahappy, but i left with a ton of new and good friends on my side who i met through the server. In the recent months i focused on getting my dream unusual (which i wanted long since before free to play was a thing). A texas ten gallon painted gold that was vivid plasma and level 3 or 33 (favorite hat, favorite paint, favorite effect and if you look at my name you can see why the level) After borrowing an entire bud from that admin mentioned above from sodahappy (the first one i met) i purchased the hat for 3.5 buds (with some extra sweets) while it was only worth 2.5. This was because the owner was super reluctant to give it up, but i needed it for its level 33. After paying off the 1 bud debt i felt complete I had a ton of tf2 stuff including my dream hat and i felt it was time to move on. So i gave a lot of my stuff away and stopped playing tf2, revisiting occasionally. Summary/TL:DR: Tf2 is my most played game of all time and i kind of grew up with it. And if i could go back and change anything i wouldn't (maybe except for that  scamming me). As much as it makes me sound like a nerd, Tf2 represents a chapter of my life and i wont soon forget it.

review: When you first play this game you'll probably suck at it and you feel like rage quitting and not playing ever again but then you keep playing and you slowly but surely get addicted like the other 50,000 who play the game. All I can say that Team Fortress 2 is another success by Valve as it is a game that you will get addicted to within 1 hour of gameplay. Team Fortress 2 is one of those games that you'll get hooked to and play for the rest of your life. It is full of fun, enjoyment and thrill. It has a variety of classes to play with which means if you're bad with one class you might be good with another class for instance I'm really bad with the Scout while I'm considerably good with the Pyro class. It has a ton of classes consisting of The Scout, Soldier, Pyro, Demoman, Heavy, Engineer, Medic, Sniper and of course the mischievous Spy! Team Fortress 2 is certainly worth your time and many people would say worth your money BUT Team Fortress 2 is a Free To Play game! Althought 95% of the players use money on the game to become premium and to trade it is still a free and fun game. Trading is a HUGE part of the game as making a profit is always on ones mind when people play Team Fortress 2. People spend tonnes of money on the game just to gamble away in a good ole SpyCrab contest or simply just to trade and make a profit. As a former successful trader in Team Fortress 2 and trader in CS:GO trading in games like these are easy and fun at times although there is the occasional scammer. Playing and trading in Team Fortress 2 and CS:GO has made me a giant profit in both games. Overall I've gotta say Team Fortress 2 is one hell of an addicting, amazing and all-rounder game! Would definitely download it and play it. But try not get too addicted. 5 Stars! Would thoroughly recommend this! -ogiX

review: Whenever someone thinks of PC gaming, they should think of Team Fortress 2. This game, along with Counter-Strike, has made the FPS genre as it stands possible. Blog posts, shot comics, and constant updates add to an ever increasingly confusing and hilariously strange back-story with absolutely no practical application in game, except to give a base for community-made hats. game-hours: 688.0
review: Team Fortress 2 is a first-person shooter and Gaben-conomy simulator. It has a moderately-sized player base, filled with a few different kinds of people. Some include: ** Nooblings asking for free items. I kid you not, this can be a nuisance when playing sometimes. ** Map-makers/editors (Otherwise known as mappers) and people that modify the game's server software to create new game modes or additions to the game (modders). Also, there are modellers, people that create and submit assets to the Workshop for consideration to be included in the game. ** Team-spirited people. There are a few game modes, the most popular being Control Points (defend control points from capture by the attacking team), Capture the Flag, Payload (deliver a bomb cart to the other team) and Mann vs Machine (6 players versus robots of varying class that arrive in waves). In most of TF2's game modes, there are nine different types of mercenary to kill or be killed as. (Most people know these as classes) The only exception is Mann vs Machine mode, where you fight robot versions of these mercenaries. However, the most popular feature of TF2 is the economy. Introduced in 2010, it relies heavily on Steam's trading service. Most items traded are hats or metal. Hat trades are serious business for some people, with sites such as TF2Outpost set up to co-ordinate trades, and some items also have real-world value, so these sites often allow users to trade items for USD/Bitcoins/<currency goes here> or Steam games.

game-hours: 580.1
review: This is not just a game one plays. Oh, sure it can be, but TF2 is an entire universe to explore. Valve's originally-humble, unique shooter has grown into an even more unique shooter that continues to stand out amongst other multiplayer-centric titles for numerous reasons, and has grown popular across the globe, dwarfing even Valve's own Counter-Strike. Is this game for everyone? Maybe not, but they're in the minority. This game stands out mainly because it continues to receive support and updates seven-plus years after its initial release, and Valve seems to figure out the next big thing from time to time. The growth of TF2 has allowed people entering into this microcosm of gaming to play it the standard way, play it more vanilla-style (like when it first came out), play a co-op mode, make replays and SFM videos, play on custom maps and modded servers, and more. All of this is at the fingertips of anyone with Steam access. See that "Play Game" button up there? Click it and give this game a shot, at least.

game-hours: 918.7
review: Possibly one of the greatest first person shooters developed, due to its unique style, character diversity and likeable personality. Though slightly hampered by the occasional chat spammer, multiplayer is relatively enjoyable overall. Would definitely recommend this game to people new to the genre - learning curve is quite shallow and the ingame tutorials as well as the community guides do much to aid new players. Those coming from a different FPS, particularly more formal and "FPSish" games like Battlefield or CoD may find it a bit hard to adjust to the different playstyles, but everyone adapts eventually.

review: A game I can have non-stop fun with Multi-class action on amazing maps with a HUGE variety of weapons to kick  with and INSANE amounts of cosmetics to show off! As of the Love & War update this game got 200% more fun, new taunts like Conga, Skullcracker, Flippin' Awesome give a new depth into the game as co-operation from both sides of the fight is pretty common now! For new players, this game may seem like a bore, because of the masses upon masses of weapons (which you may not have yet) or the large amount of maps and gamemodes that may seem new to you (Payload, Payload Race, Control Points etc.), but trust me, with 1300+ hours I can say each second was well-spent either destroying the opposing team or dancing with them! Either way this game is a blast and I definately recommend it to anyone! 95/100 Pyros are still fairly over-powered, a list of things to nerf: Speed Decrease (10%) Flamethrower DPS (10%) Backburner + Phlog Mini-crit instead of crit Sexcellent game.

game-hours: 1725.6

game-hours: 1421.4
review: This game is unfathomably good. I don't even like first-person shooters, and not only do I still like TF2, it's actively my favourite game of all time. There are 9 classes, each with different playstyles, and each with a bunch of different weapons you can use to fine-tune the class to how you want to play. It's impressive how balanced the game is - each weapon has benefits and drawbacks compared to the stock weapons you have when you first start the game. There are a few whose benefits outweigh the drawbacks and vice-versa, and a couple that are literally direct upgrades, but you never feel like you're at a huge disadvantage by not having certain weapons. The fact that the game's around 7 years old and they're still updating it is incredible. The Mann vs. Machine update added a new game mode that's a sort of tower defence game. It could have been its own $20-$30 game, but nope, Valve gave it to everyone for free. There are some advantages premium players have over free players, but none of them directly affect gameplay - Premium players can keep more items and trade. Trading makes it so easy to get weapons and Premium can cost less than a dollar, so I really don't see any reason to not upgrade yourself to Premium. I guess at some point I have to talk about hats. They seem silly, right? Why bother making so much of the content have no effect on gameplay? But that's exactly why they do it! A new weapon isn't just about modelling and scripting. You have to make sure it's balanced and can't be exploited in any way. But hats and other cosmetic items can't possibly be 'unbalanced', so of course they can add a hundred hats easier than they can add one new weapon. Maybe they could focus more on weapons, but there are already so many as it is; you don't want to make it impossible for new players to catch up. So obviously TF2 is amazing. 10/10 would play again and probably will this afternoon. There are, however, a few drawbacks. TF2's normal devotion to balance makes it all the more glaring when something isn't balanced. The Soldier has so much versatility in his weapons that it's pretty easy to call him /the best class/ in a game that's supposed to be about teamwork. It's pretty easy to see Valve playing favourites with the Soldier. If some class has a weapon that players are favouring over the other options, most of the time Valve will nerf the over-used weapon (ex. the Spy's Dead Ringer). But for the Soldier, they'll just buff the under-used weapons (ex. The Concheror and Battalion's Backup). Giving the Soldier extra upgrades in Mann vs. Machine also reeked of favouritism when it's the Spy and Pyro who needed the help. One other drawback is that the store's prices on weapons has absolutely nothing to do with how rare / common they are. This isn't really Valve's fault, but it makes a lot of things in the store complete rip-offs. Suppose you want a Phlogistinator. It costs $10 in the store. OR you could buy four Keys ($2.50 each). Each key is worth, in the trading economy, about 100 Phlogistinators. I'm not exaggerating. (Phlogistinator: 0.05 - 0.11 refined. Key: about 8.66 refined.) Basically, once you know a little bit about the economy, you feel like you have to REALLY get into it so you don't get ripped off. Or maybe that was just me.
game-hours: 792.7
review: The game is fun. The community is normally SO much better than that of Cod's or BFF's. The micro-transactions are good too. You can get almost anything from item drops in-game. And there are so many different gamemodes! You have the default ones, Doomsday, CTF, CP, but then you have community made ones (that I think some should be real ones,) Freak Fortress 2, Arena, X10, all very fun! It's also very easy to record, as you can easily set up events, give yourself a challenge, or simply shoot at things! All the classes are very different as well, and can help eachother on the same team, (Medic + Heavy) or can destroy eachother on the opposing team, (Sniper + Spy or Spy + Pyro.) Anyways, I recomend this game to everyone, even if you dislike FPS games, because to be honest, this game will never be normal. It's to late to go back.

review: I played this game over a year ago, and after getting hardware that can run Steam, coming back to Team Fortress 2 brings back the same excitement. There are nine playable classes, so it's easy to find one or more that fits your playstyle while contributing to your team's victory. Additionally, you can get items to further customize your character based on how you fight. You do have to buy a cheap item in order to expand your backpack, and playing more than ten hours a week does not grant additional items. However, this game is still practically a staple for anyone who has steam, and I've heard that the hats are pretty cool :P

game-hours: 451.3
review: Team Fortress 2 is the only competitive multiplayer shooter that I have ever played consistently. I've tried others, but in the end, I've always quit after realizing that I don't have the time to compete with the guys who can play these games all day long. I'm sure some people love memorizing all the weapon pickup locations and mastering the jumping, spinning, no-scope headshot, but that ain't me. With the game's nine very specialized classes, you're very likely to find something that really just suits your play style just right. Even as a newb, the class strengths are so drastic, you can almost always get in a few kills if you just do what your class does best. The experience is always lighthearted and 90% of the community is friendly. With loads of unlockable weapons, there's not only a lot of incentive to keep playing, but there ends up being quite a bit of customization within the nine classes as well. For instance, the Pyro's flare gun changed the entire game for me!
game-hours: 139.8

game-hours: 1602.1
review: A good game with memorable characters and decent gameplay, but with a few issues like server lags(during mvm this is a real pain in the butt) and most of the time unbalanced teams ( I mean that if one or two advanced players join in one team and the other, may it be beginner or decent players are just going to get screwed by them and most of the time leave the server). Another thing, but that does not bug me that much, is that way too many players are at the age of ten or even lower( I think I met someone who told me he was six or seven). As I said, it`s not a big deal for me, but for many other (older) players who are just annoyed by them( for example because of mic spamming). But all in all, Team Fortress 2 is a fun game.

review: Overall, i definitely recommend this game to anyone. With 9 versitile classes to choose from, hundreds of weapons, and an infinite number of playstyles for each class, tf2 is a HIGHLY addicting game. Working as a team or simply dominating by yourself, gameplay is amazing with every class. There is another aspect other than just fighting; there is trading! Many people trade on tf2 to get different types of weapons like stranges, festives, vintages, etc. and getting HATS. Some unusual hats can be worth hundreds of dollars! The best part of all, is that the game is free. And although you may have to buy that 99 cent giftapult to go premium, i believe i would have payed 60 dollars for this game, maybe more. That's just how awesome this game is :D

review: Out of all the Dress-Up Sims I have ever played this is by far the worst. There's only two uniforms you can wear, blu or red. The only redeeming quality of this Dress-up Sim is the plethora of hats one can equip to their avatar. Unfortunately in order to do this, one has to stand around doing nothing for hours on end with the chance of even FINDING one of these hats. One thing the creators of this game may want to consider is the ability to at least swap clothing between the different "characters" one can choose for their avatar. That really really big man would look much better in the suit on the scrawny guy, who in turn would look much better with a nice bowler or something instead of a sock on his head. All in all I give this game a 4/10.

review: If you haven't played this before, you may be asking yourself: "What is Team Fortress 2?" Firstly, you sound like David Byrne. Team Fortress 2 is hitting an engineer with the Force-a-Nature so hard that he flies into the air and can only watch as he falls to his death. Team Fortress 2 is getting 10 kills in a row without spinning down your minigun. Team Fortress 2 is getting all of the control points in one life. Team Fortress 2 is backstabbing every sniper on the map. Team Fortress 2 is dominating the entire other team. Team Fortress 2 is earning the trust of a Medic so he Ubercharges you and you kill the entire other team. Team Fortress 2 is backstabbing an engineer and sapping his sentry. Team Fortress 2 is knocking someone out of the map with your Atomizer. Team Fortress 2 is fighting off a horde of robots with nothing but a flamethrower and a large lollipop. review: Ok Lets talk a bit TF2. I love this game for many reasons. To the Classes to the Hats, I love everything about TF2(expect mini-sentrys). TF2 Out of all the Fps I played gave me a feeling of enjoyement like no other. Some will say that if its the gameplay, or the style of the game, or maybe the commuinty this game has. And its all of that. TF2 gamestyle is centered around 9 classes in which have complete diffrent play styles and mechanics, and that alone should be a selling point, but in addtion to that this game has diffrent weapons for each class that changes some points of game play but is true to what the class is(expect demo...but I love demoknighting). With this much varity you might say that this game might have some op stuff, and the amazing truth is that nothing is better than a other thing(expect medic and pyro melee weps) and it gives this game a curve with the sill of the player. Now back to the classes, the classes themslves are a reason to play, for the lines and personitly given to each are things that gives life into these mercs. Now one thing I have to talk about when talking about TF2 is Hats. That alone sales this game. Hats. Hats. Without poking fun of our hat sim overcomings, TF2 has cosmation on the Classes that puts some flair on them either makes your class Cool looking or just a joy to look at. These Hats give people also to start a Encomy within the game, and has no impact on the gameplay of the game other than it looks cool. I hate play to win game...but TF2 is what I call Pay to look fancy(yeah that sounds dumb). And last The commuinty whever it be the workshop, groups, reddit, or tumblur. TF2 has a Amazing commuinty in which I have seen noting negative at my time playing, but sure some commuinty's have those bad eggs yet they dont ruin the bunch like other games. And hey this game is pretty old from being a mod to its classic mode, and to the Team Fourtress we come to love this game has aged well, and I got to say I love every minute of playing it. And to finally top it all of( and I know i missed stuff but im lazy) this game still gets updates and I say that because of us who keeps on pushing that cart or wrangling them sentrys, and those who Noms away and bonks away, those who pop uber and those who pops heads. from the backstabers to the backburners. And the demos and sollys still in this war. I give this game a 10/10 would recommend to all.

game-hours: 1.0

game-hours: 691.3
review: Short Review: Virtual Hat Simulator. With Cash. (Relatively) Long Review: - Storyline The plot is simple. There is a war going on between the Builders League United (BLU) and Reliable Excavation Demolition (RED), both subsidiaries of TF Industries. However, due to problems lacking an obvious bureaucratic solution, mercenaries are contracted to address the situation through war. You join one of the two teams (not permanently) and play as one of the nine mercenaries (hereby named 'classes') which each has its own unique features in a war to Attack/Defend (e.g. Payload, Attack/Defend Control Points) or to gain control (e.g. King of the Hill, 5CP, Special Delivery) - Gameplay/Classes The nine classes all play an important role in the game and having too many (or the lack thereof) of one class leads to an imbalanced team, causing the team to suffer heavy penalties in terms of co-operating to push towards their objective. The nine classes, Scout, Soldier, Pyro, Demoman, Heavy, Engineer, Sniper Medic and Spy all have their own distinct features, ranging from invisibility cloaks to the all common 420blazeit sniper. The weapons are more or less well-balanced, in the sense that no weapon is vastly considered to be better than the stock or another weapon, although it does suit different fighting styles. With new maps (almost, or at least somewhat) consistently introduced, you get a different gameplay each time as you encounter players who genuinely help the team, players who go in alone and complains no one is there to help, or players who are so accurate with their shots and low ping you don't stand a chance (unless you lag shot them with your 500 ping). You might also join a "friendly" server where you see players just taunting and "Conga-ing" or walking around, and killing them earns you a kick or a callout for a . - Weapons Most weapons are attained through item drops which occur as you play, so as to "encourage playing" until the item drop cap for that week is reached. Strange and Festive variants can be obtained by using keys (purchased with Steam Wallet) to unlock normal, rare and seasonal crates. These are however, purely cosmetic and do not affect gameplay in anyway (besides distracting you). Using the weapons you get, you can craft them into another weapon of your liking or even get a chance to craft a more uncommon reskin weapon, such as the Mauler and Sharp Dresser. Some weapons can also be obtained via achievements and in general, the weapons are considered sidegrades -- except for several Medic melee weapons, all the weapons can be considered to be both better and worse than the stock weapon you are given. - Cosmetics Team Fortress is well-known for its hat simulator. Using the weapon drops you get, you can craft them into Refined Metals and eventually recombine them to get a common (named as 'Unique' ingame) quality hat (TF2 Premium DLC is required, obtained upon any in-game store purchase). Rarely, you may also get hats or even taunts via item drops. This purely decorates your character but does most of the gameplay here. See that cool-looking unusual guy? Aim him. See that "noob" gibus guy? Aim him. See that guy with a thousand kills on his strange weapon? Aim him. That "vanilla" guy who just started playing? Aim him. (That was rubbish) The cosmetics also run all of the trading in TF2 and it is what allows you to actually earn (or lose) money (in terms of keys) and/or Steam Wallet (by selling the keys on the market). If you are lucky during an unbox, you can also get an Unusual-quality cosmetic or taunt, basically a normal cosmetic or taunt with an additional effect, and this fetches a very high price in the market due to its highly valued effects (market and player dependent). - Economy I will not go deep into this, but it's pretty safe to say that you can play the game fine if you do not care for cosmetics and you can simply find some traders or trading sites to exchange for the weapon you want. There is a large amount of reviews and opinions regarding TF2 trading, ranging from "easy to earn stuff" to "too many sharks/scammers/profiteers" and "impossible to earn stuff" etc. As such, trading is based on their own personal experience which is unique to almost everyone and this cannot exactly be reviewed.

game-hours: 1343.0
review: You probably know what this game is. Lets be honest, everyone has probably heard of Team Fortress 2 the moment they got on steam. Team Fortress 2 is a free-to-play shooter with a cartoony art style, and an unusual way of playing that sets it apart from other shooters. In Team Fortress 2, there are 9 classes, each with its weaknesses and advantages. Along with the basic shooting, classes have their own unique abilities that help on the battlefield. However, this game is not only famous for the click & shoot, it has one of the most interesting (and complicated) economy that I enjoy to participate in. You can work your way up to be able trade in-game items for actual steam games. This game also doesn't tax your machine and even on low settings is lovable with it's computer-friendly artstyle. Even though it's been released a long time ago, Team Fortress 2 still maintains it's freshness and uniqueness.

game-hours: 321.7
review: Wow, what an amazing game... To start off, I have got to say this is probably one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played. Team Fortress 2 provides the experience that no other shooter provides. It is loaded with action, comedy, and most importantly, HATS! The new taunts/hats/weapons added to this game are incredible! The community is amazing, and the workshop is just fun to browse through. There is so many original ideas that it is hard to believe! Team Fortress 2 also is the best class shooter games out there, and also provides the option of customization! With the customization, you can put sick shades on your character, or put a cardigan on. It is your choice. Customization also includes choosing your weapons (changing your stock weapon to a unique weapon, such as the Quick-Fix) and choosing taunts. Taunts can be as zany as throwing fried chicken, or it can also be as simple as laughing at the opponent. The options are almost endless! The weapons are special in there own way as well. You can put a sheen and effect on it (if you get a special kit) which allows you to pimp out your weapon! Weapons also can be renamed and descriptionized, so there is no fear of a terribly named weapon. Team Fortress 2 is also amazing because it is not "Pay 2 Win". Team Fortress 2 gives you almost all of the normal options a premium has, such as hats, taunts, and finding weapons. Oh, I forgot to mention about the weapon drop system. In this game, you are capable of finding any weapon in the game (except for promotional game items). In added bonus if you get premium is that you can also find hats! I once found an All-Father, which is an amazing beard! Team Fortress 2 also has its own economy. That's right! The economy is used to buy items you desire, without having to buy it with real money or waiting to find it! In conclusion, I enjoy Team Fortress 2 a LOT, and recommend this to all! Oh, and here are some ratings: Enjoy Factor= 10/10 Original Factor= 9/10 (it is a shooter, which has been done, but it stands out!) Friendliness Factor (Community)= 10/10 Smoothness Factor (how long you can play it)= 10/10 OVERALL SCORE= 9.75 Thank you for reading my review, and have a fun time gaming! -Detective Doge "The Almighty and Original Doge"

review: First, let me just say that this game is the most amazing FPS I own at the time. Do you know what makes this even better? ITS FREE! review: Team Fortress 2 is one of the best Free to Play Action Games out in virtual entertainment. This game is free; the illustration is not overpowering, but playful and provides a satisfying mood and the performance of in-game action and the game istelf is sensational. 9 classes to play and master and a myriad of maps and servers to aquaint yourself with. As a consequence, a perfect equillibrium of competition and playfulness is established; One of the most intruiging aspects of this game. Furthermore, once you become satisfied with your efforts in-game, your temptation for miscallaneous items and unusuals,stranges eg. will become un-challengeable. You might waste all your money on this game for virtual items, or possibly make a single investment and further expand your virtual inventory with virtual currency. The only downfall it seems, is the frustration of being dominated by players far superior than yourself, however, with time your skills will be able to fairly match those that were once your nemsis. In conclusion after over a thousand hours, I believe my experience is valid and dependable to give you viewers and other fellow Team Fortress 2 comrades an oppertunity to further appreciate and give an insight to Team Fortress 2. This is my absolute and mode game that I have ever indulged myself (or Runescape), even as fast approaching adult. I enjoy this game, and hopefully so do you :) Wishing you all success in your virtual endeavours! - Geebert

game-hours: 617.7
review: TEAM FORTRESS 2 RECOMMENDATION REDUX EDITION WITH BONUS DLC HAT: Tired of fighting in MODERN WARZONES? Team Fortress 2 takes you to a wonderful humourous world where two groups battle it out for buisness. Team Fortress 2 is a class-based shooter that focuses on objective-based game types, featuring 9 playable with their own set of perks and traits to assist you in your playstyle. Before you read/play, if you're used to your common MODERN FPS skills, that's all in the trash here. Nothing of what you played before will carry over effectively into this game, which means there's a lot of new learning to be done in terms of combat effectiveness. Each class plays with variety and it can take some time to getting used to, but once you find your "main class" then it'll be a breeze from then on their. Scout is fast, Soldier does damage, Pyro burns, Engineer builds turrets, Heavy tanks, Demoman traps, Medics heal, Snipers... snipe, Spies stealth. Pretty simple, but each of their mechanics have some time getting used to, you can't expect to be a great Spy if you main Scout. A lot of these classes work in conjunction with each other and have their own proper counters. The game features a lot of unlockable weapons and aesthetic items for each of the classes as well, with major differences to alter their gameplay. Now you're thinking, Balance... Right? The game itself remains balanced most of the time, however, along with its ever-changing updates, their has been some weapons released that are slightly more powerful than they should be. However, thankfully, Valve is quick to fix it. (Valve and Quick in the same sentence.. that's weird) The setting takes place in a wacky and cartoon world set aroudn the 1960s, the game is humourous and the characters feature a wonderful set of personality I have yet to see in a multiplayer shooter. Many of the aesthetics features hats and misc. items such as beards and mask that you can decorate your character with (if you like) The game also features a prominent trading community, but if you don't want to deal with people I recommend using TF2WH which features bots. That's about it, the game is Free-To-Play too, so why not? (It's not Pay-To-Win either) Team Fortress 2 reinvents the old forumla of fragfest into a smart reinvention and redemption of a gamestyle long lost in a sea of "Realistic" shooters.

game-hours: 950.0
review: TF2 or Team Fortress 2, is a great game with fundamental features that makes it one of the most unique games I have ever played. There are several elements that go into a game that make a good game, well-good. GRAPHICS/ART STYLE The graphics for TF2, isn't the most amazing, but with the artstyle it has, it makes the game fun and enjoyable. The characters are expertly created and always find a way to make you laugh. Whether Spy's back stabbing, rude nature, to Heavy's "stoopid" like appearance. GAMEPLAY This is a no-brainer it seems. The game is perfectly balanced and gives no one and edge. However classes may seem to counter a certain class, but with different items, you can counter them. An example is the Pyro and Spy. Pyro can easily find the Spy, no matter what sneaky beaky hiding spot he may have, but, with help from the spy-cicle or the dead ringer, the Spy can fool the Pyro (Unless you play competetivly, then thats a different story). LEVEL DESIGN Being a level designer myself, I love to have well made, well balanced maps to play on. And boy, does VALVe get a gold star on this! Sure, some maps can be a bit defender sided (Hoodoo, Dustbowl), but with a good team a good communication, you can power through any enemy defences (Unless you play competetivly, then thats a different story). BONUSES I've covered all the fundamentals game mechanics that I see, but what about the other part? The drops? Trading? Hats? I mean, its nick-named Hat Simulator 2014 for a reason, right? Hahahah, correct you are! TF2 awards players who play any where from 20 minutes to 2 hours with a random drop! Whether its a weapon, hat, or a big  yo-I MEAN CRATE. With these items, you can craft them, or trade them! And the more virtual items you have, the more...virtual items you have... CONCLUSION I (and my 900+ hours) highly recommend this game, and its free! So why not?

review: Not just another mindless shoot 'em up FPS like most games, Team Fortress 2 offers unique bonuses to each class, giving it a slight RPG feel, as certain classes can counter others, such as spy beats engineer, pyro beats spy, heavy beats pyro. Many feel as though classes like the engineer are over powered, the only one that's over powered is the scout, as he can deal high amounts of damage, while circling around you, avoiding being hit, what makes it worse, he has an item, to literally, make him untouchable for a short period of time, not even a level three sentry, which can take a heavy, head on, can touch a scout who drank Bonk, and with the new update, scouts who have the newest weapon, are even more over powered, scouts are already hard to hit, and can easily get behind you, and the new weapon deal bonus damage from behind for the scout!

game-hours: 2802.5
review: More than just a FPS. Three things are needed to win, FPS skill, Class Skill and Team Skill When first playing, no matter what, it's going to seem unfair. FPS Skill: The weapons aren't "better" than the default. All weapons have their pros and cons. Each weapon is a synchronization to you. If you don't use airblast often and like to ambush players from behind. The Pyro's BackBurner is for you! Find a weapon whos cons don't weigh you down to much. If you're an airblasting pyro pro, don't chose the weapon without airblast! Class Skill: How good you are with your class, know your classes weakness and strengths! Snipers and Heavies are Spy's favorite backstab targets. So know to always watch your back. Team Skill: Also known as "Team Responsibility" No matter how good you are, how synchronized you are with your weapon. If your team does not have the right classes selected. You WILL lose. If your team needs a Medic, be that Medic, Spy? Be that Spy! It is up to you to decide which class will be the most helpful to your team. TF2 is a great game! Good Luck!

game-hours: 1999.6
review: Amazing. Valve figured out how to do F2P properly. It's super balanced, so even the newbie can kill the veteran. All the classes are unique and genuinely have to work together to survive. Each class as a nemesis. Just got killed from half a mile away by a sniper? Go spy and stab him. Spy stabbed you? Go pyro and barbecue his . Get barbecued? Go scout and beat him to death with a floppy fish. Got beaten to death by a floppy fish? etc. If you can find a decent server with players who actually know what they're doing, it's worth it. There's even a trading economy if you're more of a thinker. All the weapons are equally powerful, even the defaults. The extra weapons aren't upgrades, they're sidegrades so you can tweak your play style. The default scout shotgun is good on it's own, but you can replace it with a sawn off double barelled type thing with more damage, but with knockback and only two shots. That sort of thing.

game-hours: 1467.9
review: If you like Team Deathmatch, this is the game for you, simialar to Ace Of Spades. It has many gamemodes from capture the flag to king of the hill. TF2 has something for everyone! Give it a shot! Hit me up and I'll play with you! There are many different game modes to the game, almost somthing for everyone. The game is based more on a team effort, its not just about you. Keep that in mind while playing, it'll help you and your team get a lot better. If pubbing isnt for you and you're a really good player, there is competitive Team Fortress to play (haven't really tried it, heard its good). This game you can "trade" virtual items in, which is actually how I have been able to buy most of my games without a cost to me. I have loved Team Fortress for well over a year and I hope to play it much longer. A++
